text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
The following material changes have been made since the prior revision:

IRM Reference Description of Change 4.11.51.1 Subsection title changed from References to Program Scope and Objectives. Subsections added to address program background, authority, responsibilities, program reports, acronyms, terms, and related resources. 4.11.51.1.1 Content previously contained in IRM 4.11.51.2 regarding an overview of the Return Preparer Program has been moved to IRM 4.11.51.1.1. 4.11.51.3 Reference to Return Preparer Program replaced with Program Action Case. Paragraph order modiﬁed to improve readability. 4.11.51.3.3 Content wording modiﬁed to clarify what actions should be considered when examiners discover a ghost preparer. 4.11.51.3.4 Subsection title changed from Representation Overview to Representation Overview - Unenrolled Return Preparers. Paragraph added to deﬁne Unenrolled Return Preparer. 4.11.51.4 Content wording modiﬁed to include consideration of IRM 4.10.5.4.1, Analysis of Related and Spin-Off Returns. 4.11.51.5 Duplicate content removed. References to the Exam third-party contact IRM 4.11.57 were replaced with the Servicewide third-party contact IRM 25.27. 4.11.51.6.1 Updated subsection title to better describe content. Added paragraph (4) to provide instructions to specialty exam. 4.11.51.6.1.1 Subsection added to provide instructions to RPCs when they discover preparers who are non-ﬁlers or otherwise not current in their personal tax compliance. Content added to comply with recommendation from TIGTA Audit Number 201830039. 4.11.51.6.3 Content wording modiﬁed to clarify when a referral to Office of Professional Re- sponsibility (OPR) is required. Content wording modiﬁed to clarify the steps an examiner must take when they receive a referral from OPR. 4.11.51 Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses,
Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This IRM supersedes IRM 4.11.51 dated September 23, 2016.
Examination personnel in SB/SE and LB&I.
Maha H. Williams

page (
) Purpose: This IRM section serves as a reference guide on Return Preparer Program procedures for examiners. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all SB/SE and LB&I examiners. (
) Policy Owner: The Director, Examination - Field and Campus Policy, under Director, Headquarters Examination. (
) IRM Owner: Field Examination Special Processes, under the Director, nation - Field and Campus Policy. (
) Primary Stakeholders: SB/SE and LB&I examiners. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other suggestions related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) The Return Preparer Program (RPP) is an agency-wide effort to enforce pliance of tax return preparers. Tax return preparers are a critical component tax administration and provide a unique opportunity to impact taxpayer behavior and compliance with tax laws. The IRS encourages compliance among tax return preparers through a variety of means by providing targeted enforcement activities to identify and address the most egregious return preparers. The Return Preparer Program includes all tax return preparers - only self-identiﬁed return preparers. All business units under the Services Enforcement Organization have tax return preparer strategies, including the Return Preparer Office (RPO), the Office of Professional Responsibility Return Integrity Compliance Services (W&I RICS), and Examination. (

(1) The following table lists acronyms commonly used throughout this IRM and their deﬁnitions: Acronym Deﬁnition AFSP Annual Filing Season Program AIMS Audit Information Management System CFR Code of Federal Regulations CI Criminal Investigation DOJ Department of Justice ESAM External Services Authorization Management IDRS Integrated Data Retrieval System LB&I Large Business and International LDC Lead Development Center OPR Office of Professional Responsibility PAC Program Action Case POA Power of Attorney PSC Preparer Steering Committee PSP Planning and Special Programs

The following table lists commonly used terms and associated deﬁnitions refer- enced throughout this IRM:

A return (including an amended or adjusted return) ﬁled by or on behalf of a taxpayer reporting the liability of the taxpayer for tax under the Code, if the type of return is identiﬁed in published guidance in the Internal Revenue Bulletin. A tax return also includes any information return or other document identiﬁed in published guidance in the Internal Revenue Bulletin and that reports information that is or may be reported on another taxpayer’s return under the Code if the information reported on the information return or other document constitutes a substantial portion of the taxpayer’s return. Any person who prepares for compensation, or who employs one or more persons to prepare for compensation, all or a substantial portion of any tax

) The RPC is responsible for planning and coordinating the implementation of the Area and National Return Preparer Strategy. RPCs provide direction, knowledge and guidance on tax return preparer related issues. Their duties include receiving and evaluating referrals regarding potential preparer duct, initiating and monitoring Program Action Cases and assisting with and reviewing preparer penalty cases. (

) Examples of when to contact your RPC include, but are not limited to: • A return that appears to have questionable preparation issues • Suspected preparer misconduct • Issues involving Powers of Attorney • Assistance in obtaining information on a PTIN • Assistance with completing a preparer referral • Questions about documentation needed to support a preparer • Assistance with establishing and completing a preparer penalty case (

) RPCs are the liaison between ﬁeld employees and the RPO, OPR and IRS Headquarter functions. All questions and concerns should be elevated the Area RPC. For more guidance on Return Preparer Coordinator duties, to IRM
, Return Preparer Program Coordinator. (

) A tax return preparer is anyone who prepares for compensation, or employs one or more persons to prepare for compensation, any tax return or claim refund. The deﬁnition of a tax return preparer is addressed in Treas. Reg.
(Link:
CFR

). All tax return preparers who are required to sign a return must properly identify themselves with their PTIN all tax returns for which they were compensated for preparing. Note: More than one individual can be the preparer of a taxpayer’s tax return. Each preparer of the return generally must have a PTIN, but only one sign and enter their PTIN. Per Treas. Reg.

) During the examination of a noncompliant return preparer, erroneously returns may be identiﬁed. (

) A Program Action Case (PAC) allows for the examination of returns by a particular tax return preparer, if information indicates a pattern of pliance. Area Director approval is required prior to initiating a PAC to the returns of a tax return preparer’s client(s). (

) The Area RPC gathers information on tax return preparers from various sources. This includes: Return a. Information received from examiners (main source) b. Preparer penalty records c. Information items d. Referrals from other functions See IRM
, PAC Inventory Sources, for additional sources of referrals. (

) The RPC maintains records containing information on return preparer When a pattern of noncompliance is recognized, the IRS will consider prohibit the tax return preparer from practicing before the IRS. Preparer will be limited to cases where information indicates a tax return preparer engaged in a widespread practice of making material errors. This conduct demonstrates intentional misconduct or clear incompetence in preparing income tax returns. (

) When submitting information about a noncompliant return preparer, be as speciﬁc as possible about noncompliance. Provide as much of the information as possible: • Identiﬁcation of the tax return preparer • Name and taxpayer identifying number of the examined taxpayer(s) • Examples of the noncompliance • First two pages of the examiner’s report • Source of the information which resulted in a referral • Copies of preparer penalties asserted (
) See IRM
, SB/SE and LB&I Return Preparer Referrals, for ting referrals regarding noncompliant preparers. (
) Ghost preparers are preparers who fail to properly identify themselves in cordance with IRC

, Identifying numbers. All compensated return preparers must have a PTIN. Ghost preparers are deﬁned as preparers • Omit any identiﬁcation information - making the return appear to be prepared. • Report a false or fabricated identiﬁcation number on the tax return with the IRS. • Report a valid identiﬁcation number which is assigned to another vidual on the tax return ﬁled with the IRS. (
) If an examiner encounters a potential ghost preparer issue during an tion, the following should be considered: (

) The examiner should attempt to obtain as much information about the tax return preparer from the taxpayer as possible in order to support the penalty. (

)(iii)), an unenrolled preparer may only represent a taxpayer before Revenue Agents, Customer Service Representatives, or similar and employees of the Internal Revenue Service (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) during an examination of the tax period covered by the return they prepared and signed (or prepared if there is no signature space the form). (

) The IRS has a voluntary program called the Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) that recognizes the efforts of non-credentialed return preparers who aspire to a higher level of professionalism. Those who participate can meet requirements by obtaining a certain number of continuing education hours in preparation for a speciﬁc tax year. They must also renew their PTIN for the upcoming year and consent to adhere to the obligations in Treasury Depart- ment Circular
, Subpart B, Section
) Participation in the AFSP provides unenrolled return preparers with limited resentation rights. They are permitted to represent taxpayers before the IRS under Rev. Proc.
, which supersedes Rev. Proc.
) According to Rev. Proc.
, in order for unenrolled return preparers to represent taxpayers for tax returns ﬁled after December

, they must: • Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the calendar year(s) in which the tax return was ﬁled, and • Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the year(s) in which the representation occurs. Note: For tax returns ﬁled prior to December
, unenrolled return can follow the rules of representation in Rev. Proc.

) Examiners can determine if an unenrolled return preparer holds a current AFSP Record of Completion by searching the Directory of Federal Tax Preparers with Credentials and Select Qualiﬁcations on www.irs.gov (http:// irs.treasury.gov/rpo/rpo.jsf). (

) Examiners can determine if an unenrolled return preparer holds a prior year AFSP Record of Completion by reviewing the Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) Participants list located on the RPO webpage gov/RPO/Pages/Home.aspx).

According to Rev. Proc. 2014-42, in order for unenrolled return preparers to represent taxpayers for tax returns ﬁled after December 31, 2015, they must:
Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the calendar year(s) in which the tax return was ﬁled, and Have a valid AFSP Record of Completion in the year(s) in which the representation occurs.
Note: For tax returns ﬁled prior to December 31, 2015, unenrolled return preparers can follow the rules of representation in Rev. Proc. 81-38.

) Examiners can determine if an unenrolled return preparer holds a current AFSP Record of Completion by searching the Directory of Federal Tax Return Preparers with Credentials and Select Qualiﬁcations on www.irs.gov (http:// irs.treasury.gov/rpo/rpo.jsf). (

) When the information compiled by the RPC indicates a pattern of noncompli- ance with the returns prepared, a PAC may be initiated.
When the information compiled by the RPC indicates a pattern of noncompli- ance with the returns prepared, a PAC may be initiated.
Program

) IRS can only identify returns prepared by a particular preparer if the properly identiﬁed themselves on the return. Therefore, examiners should request a list of all individual and business returns prepared by the preparer under the authority of IRC
, Tax return preparer must furnish copy of return to taxpayer and must retain a copy or list. (

) The RPC orders a sample of returns from these lists as well as the preparer inventory list (PIL) and reviews them for audit potential. If the RPC there is sufficient audit potential in the sample, the RPC will request concur- rence from the PSC to initiate a PAC. (
) Upon concurrence, the RPC will obtain clearance from the LDC (IRM
) and CI (IRM
) to ensure there are no conﬂicts with an existing preparer or CI investigation. (

) Upon receipt of LDC and CI clearances, the PSC will submit a program request memorandum to the Area Director, through the Territory Manager, approval. If not approved by the Area Director, a PAC will not be initiated no action will be taken. (
) If approved, the RPC will establish the cases on AIMS. (

) By pursuing preparer penalties when warranted, preparers will be educated proper tax preparation techniques and procedures. Addressing a tax return preparer’s noncompliant behavior will have an impact on the tax returns they prepare. Correcting an unlawful tax return preparer can have an exponential impact on the tax compliance of many tax returns. (
) During an examination of the client taxpayer’s return, do not disclose a preparer penalty decision to the taxpayer or preparer. (
) The examination case of the related client should be closed prior to ing the preparer penalty case. (
) Consideration of tax return preparer penalties under IRC
and IRC required on all examinations. (

) Examination employees should consider compliance of the tax return during every examination. SB/SE and LB&I examination employees address noncompliance of return preparers through proposed preparer penalties and referrals to the Area RPC. Examination employees should not send referrals RPO to address noncompliant return preparers in lieu of penalty Some common examples of noncompliance that should have penalty ations and a referral to the Area RPC include: • PTIN requirement violations, • Egregious errors and/or omissions on client tax returns, and • A pattern of noncompliance by the tax return preparer. (

) If a tax return preparer is not personally tax compliant, the examination employee should discuss with the group manager and Area RPC the of examining the tax preparer’s return or completing an information referral (See: IRM
, Analysis of Related and Spin-Off Returns).
(10-30-2020) Preparer Penalties Overview

• A pattern of noncompliance by the tax return preparer. If a tax return preparer is not personally tax compliant, the examination employee should discuss with the group manager and Area RPC the viability of examining the tax preparer’s return or completing an information referral (See: IRM
, Analysis of Related and Spin-Off Returns).

) All tax return preparers must have a PTIN or other prescribed identifying number that was applied for and received in the manner prescribed by the in Treas. Reg.
(d) (Link:
CFR
(d)) and Notice
If PTIN is not present on the return in question, or is present but not active, tax return preparer may be subject to a penalty under IRC

(c), Failure furnish identifying number. Examiners should be aware of the following stances where a penalty may apply: • Multiple individuals using the same PTIN. • Not including the PTIN of the signing preparer in the paid preparer section of the tax return ﬁled with the IRS. • The signing preparer is employed by a ﬁrm and they fail to include ﬁrm’s EIN in the paid preparer section. • A PTIN not following the format of: nine (
) characters beginning the letter P. • Use of the preparer’s Social Security Number in lieu of a PTIN. (
) Examiners may ﬁnd more information on preparer penalties at IRM
, Penalty Handbook, Preparer, Promoter, Material Advisor Penalties. (
) IRC

, Rules for application of assessable penalties, treats preparer penalties as taxes. Therefore, when an examiner makes contact with other than the preparer to determine if the preparer is liable for a penalty, party notiﬁcation may be required. (
) If a preparer’s client(s) are examined for the purpose of determining the preparer is subject to a preparer penalty AND if the ﬁve factors found the deﬁnition of Treas. Reg
(b) (Link:

(b)) met, third-party contact procedures must be followed. (

Is made with respect to the determination or collection of the tax of such taxpayer;
Discloses the identity of the taxpayer being investigated; and
Discloses the association of the IRS employee with the IRS. (

) For every third-party contact, the examiner must advise the third party (including clients of the preparer) before the conclusion of the initial interview that the IRS is required by law to provide their name to the as a third-party contact. There is an exception to this notiﬁcation if the third party client believes that notifying the preparer may result in reprisal against themselves or any person. The examiner should accept the third party’s response at face value. The examiner may also make the reprisal tion based on the facts and circumstances of the case. Note: In order to adhere to third-party contact procedures, examiners should advise clients of the preparer they were selected for audit as part of a preparer compliance review and ask if they fear reprisal (See: IRM
, Reprisal Notiﬁcation Procedures). Examiners should not any more information regarding the preparer than is necessary to conduct the examination of the client. (
) If an IRS employee determines that providing the advance notice or a record of a speciﬁc contact to a taxpayer may result in a reprisal - an act of or retaliation - against any person, refer to IRM
, Reprisal, for in- structions on completing Form

, Third Party Contact Report Form. Caution: Ensure information about an individual fearing reprisal is not disclosed. Information in the case ﬁle referencing the identity of the party should be placed in a conﬁdential envelope and clearly marked. (
) Refer to IRM
, Program Action Cases Overview (PAC), for on PACs. Note: IRC

) provides that Service employees may make investigative closures to the extent necessary in obtaining information, which is not otherwise reasonably available, with respect to the correct determination of tax, liability for tax, or the amount to be collected. See IRM
, Re- quirements for Investigative Disclosures, for additional guidance. (
) Refer to IRM
, Third-Party Contact Program, for speciﬁc third-party contact guidance. (

The examiner should accept the third party’s response at face value. The examiner may also make the reprisal tion based on the facts and circumstances of the case. Note: In order to adhere to third-party contact procedures, examiners should advise clients of the preparer they were selected for audit as part of a preparer compliance review and ask if they fear reprisal (See: IRM

When appropriate, SB/SE examiners will make a referral to their Area RPC on Form 14719, Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Return Preparer Form 14719 should be forwarded via e-mail to the Area RPC where the practi- tioner resides. The e-mail address for your Area RPC can be found on Form
Examining Officers Guide (

) When appropriate, LB&I examiners will e–mail the LB&I RPC explaining the reason for the referral, including the tax return preparer’s name, address, identiﬁcation number, the taxpayer’s name and identiﬁcation number, and an explanation of the noncompliance identiﬁed on the part of the tax return preparer. (
) Examination employees should also adhere to procedures for making other types of tax return preparer referrals per IRM
, Examination Officers Guide (EOG), Power of Attorney Rights and Responsibilities. Examiners contact their Area’s RPC for guidance on making referrals. (
) Specialty Tax examiners should consult with their RPC for appropriate form and procedures. (
) While performing their duties under IRM

, Area Return Preparer ordinator (RPC) Responsibilities, RPCs may encounter preparers who are ﬁlers or otherwise not current in their personal tax compliance. RPCs should - RPC research the preparer’s activities to develop a non-ﬁler referral on Form Examination Information Report, using the following tools and other available resources: • Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) Command Code RPVUE – determine number of returns prepared for each non-ﬁled year to in approximating income. • External Services Authorization Management (ESAM) database – to determine if the preparer is also an Electronic Filing Identiﬁcation Number (EFIN) holder and determine how many returns were ted for each non-ﬁled year to assist in approximating income. • Return Preparer Database - PTIN Compliance, complaints that clues to income, theft of refund, etc. • Accurint. (
) The Area RPC will forward Form
and additional research to the Area PSP Information Referral Coordinator for processing. (

) SB/SE and LB&I examiners who encounter non-compliant preparers should consult with their manager regarding potential preparer penalties when Office priate. As it is more efficient to address the issue(s) while already engaged with the preparer, examiners should not send referrals to the RPO in lieu of penalty consideration. (
) The public and IRS non-enforcement employees may send a referral to using Form
, Return Preparer Complaint, for suspected misconduct. Based on speciﬁc criteria, the RPO will forward the referral to the Exam RPC for consideration. Form
has instructions on when to use the and when to send a referral to RPO.

) OPR supports the IRS strategy to enhance enforcement of the tax law by ensuring that tax professionals adhere to tax practice standards and follow law. OPR is the governing body responsible for interpreting and applying the Regulations Governing Practice before the Internal Revenue Service
) OPR addresses behavior that is willful, reckless or incompetent. The OPR mission is to educate and reach out to people who practice before the IRS who are subject to Circular

OPR has jurisdiction over practice by attorneys, certiﬁed public accountants, enrolled agents, enrolled actuaries appraisers. OPR does not regulate unenrolled preparers. Any matters of mis- conduct on the part of an unenrolled preparer should be referred to the local RPC for consideration and resolution. (

) SB/SE and LB&I employees should send referrals to OPR for disreputable conduct and incompetence involving attorneys, certiﬁed public accountants, enrolled agents, enrolled actuaries and appraisers. Examples of misconduct under Circular
that may warrant a referral to OPR are found in IRM
, Referrals to the Office of Professional Responsibility. SB/SE employees may send referrals to OPR after they take Title

) The SB/SE LDC: • receives, identiﬁes and develops leads on individuals and entities that promote or aid in the promotion of abusive tax schemes and/or tax return preparers, • authorizes civil investigations when necessary, • evaluates and develops information from internal and external (
) The LDC is responsible for the approval of all SB/SE IRC

and IRC investigations of promoters/preparers. The LDC coordinates with CI, Counsel and DOJ to ensure appropriate penalties and/or sanctions are pursued when warranted, and provides ﬁeld support for ongoing investigations. (

) The LDC authorizes investigations of potentially abusive tax return preparers as well as promoters of abusive tax schemes. Authorized investigations are assigned to specially trained examiners through the Abusive Transaction Issues Area PSP Coordinator. A deﬁnition of abusive transactions can be in IRM
, Abusive Transactions Deﬁned. (
) The public can report suspected promoters of illegal tax schemes or abusive tax return preparers by mailing or faxing a completed Form
, Report Suspected Abusive Tax Promotions or Preparers, as well as any available documentation regarding the promotion or activity to: Internal Revenue Service Lead Development Center Stop MS
Avila Road Laguna Niguel, CA
EEFax:
Complete Part III of Form 14624, Return Form 14624 to OPR prior to the case closing from the group.
If a tax return preparer fraud referral to CI is considered, contact your local RPC and Fraud Enforcement Advisor to discuss the suspected return preparer
4.11.51.6.5 (10-30-2020) Criminal Investigation (CI) Referrals

If a tax return preparer fraud referral to CI is considered, contact your RPC and Fraud Enforcement Advisor to discuss the suspected return fraud. Some examples of return preparer fraud include: • Inﬂating income, deductions, credits, or withholding without the er’s knowledge • Diverting refunds into the bank account of the return preparer Referrals to CI can be made on Form

, Referral Report of Potential Criminal Fraud Cases. Examiners should develop the issue to establish indicators of fraud/willfulness, including, but not limited to: • A description of the ﬁrm indicators/willfulness • Taxpayer’s explanation of the ﬁrm indicators/willfulness • The estimated criminal liability
) If the criminal referral is declined, or if the criminal case is resolved, should retain a copy of the related taxpayer’s examination report (Form and relevant workpapers so the IRC
civil return preparer penalties be pursued. See IRM
, Return Preparers, IRM
, Return Preparer Fraud, and IRM
, Return Preparer Misconduct Program, for ditional information. (

) Examiners should be alert to unscrupulous tax return preparers. tax return preparers may alter tax data and/or misdirect a portion or all of a Preparer refund. The IRS has established a Policy Statement (P
) per IRM Policy Statements for Special Topics, which covers procedures for victims tax return preparer misconduct. (

) If an examiner is made aware of tax return preparer misconduct by a they will take actions to correct the taxpayer’s account. Please see IRM Return Preparer Misconduct Program, for more information. (
